title: Cast a Spell
subtitle: Cast time of 1 bonus action
description: Cast a swift spell with a casting time of 1 bonus action, but doing so restricts further spellcasting on your turn.

bullets.content: Bonus action spells provide incredible flexibility, but come with a very specific and important restriction on what other spells you can cast in the same turn. This rule prevents spellcasters from casting multiple powerful spells in a single round.

items: Bonus Action Spell Rule: If you cast any spell (cantrip or leveled) as a Bonus Action, the only other spell you can cast on the same turn is a cantrip with a casting time of 1 Action.
You cannot cast a spell as a Bonus Action and another leveled spell as an Action in the same turn.
Example: If you cast Misty Step (a bonus action), you can only use your action to cast a cantrip like Fire Bolt or take a non-spell action like Attack or Dodge.

bullets.content: This rule is a cornerstone of spellcasting action economy. Understanding it is critical to playing any spellcasting class effectively.

title: Two-Weapon Fighting
subtitle: Use with the Attack action
description: When taking the Attack action with a Light weapon, use your bonus action to make one attack with a second Light weapon.

bullets.content: This is the classic dual-wielding rule, allowing you to trade your bonus action for an additional attack. This increases your offensive output at the cost of using a shield or a two-handed weapon.

items: When you take the Attack action and attack with a weapon that has the Light property, you can use a Bonus Action to attack with a different Light weapon that you're holding in another hand.
You don't add your ability modifier to the damage of the bonus attack, unless that modifier is negative.
The Warrior group's 'Fighting Style' feature (Two-Weapon Fighting) allows you to add your ability modifier to this bonus attack's damage.
The Dual Wielder feat allows you to use weapons for this that don't have the Light property.

bullets.content: Note that some weapons with the new Nick property allow for an extra attack without using a bonus action at all, making them highly desirable for dual-wielders and freeing up the bonus action for other uses.

title: Use Class Feature
subtitle: Some features use bonus actions
description: Activate a class, species, or other feature that uses a bonus action, as specified in its description.

bullets.content: Many of the most iconic class abilities are activated as a bonus action, allowing characters to perform their signature moves while still taking a main action like attacking or casting a spell.

items: Examples: A Barbarian entering a Rage, a Rogue's Cunning Action, or a Cleric's War Priest feature. Many Channel Divinity options also use a bonus action.

bullets.content: Managing your bonus action is a key part of mastering these classes, as it often competes with other options like two-weapon fighting or bonus action spells.

title: Aim*
subtitle: Gain advantage on an attack
description: As a bonus action, forgo all your movement for the turn to grant yourself advantage on your next attack roll.

bullets.content: This optional rule provides a clear trade-off: sacrifice mobility for accuracy. It's a fantastic option for ranged characters or anyone with a single, high-impact attack who can afford to stand still.

items: This action allows you to trade all of your movement for a higher chance to hit.
You must not have moved yet on your turn.
Using this bonus action reduces your speed to 0 for the rest of the turn.

bullets.content: This is a great way for Rogues to ensure their Sneak Attack hits, or for a Sharpshooter-feat user to offset the -5 attack penalty with advantage.

title: Overrun*
subtitle: Run through a hostile space
description: As an action or bonus action, attempt to force your way through a hostile creature's space via a contested Athletics check.

bullets.content: This optional rule allows strong characters to use brute force to break through an enemy line by initiating a contest of strength. It can be used as an action or, more flexibly, a bonus action.

items: As an action or a bonus action, the mover makes a Strength (Athletics) check contested by the hostile creature's Strength (Athletics) check.
The mover has advantage on the check if it is larger than the hostile creature, or disadvantage if it is smaller.
If the mover wins the contest, it can move through the hostile creature's space once this turn.

bullets.content: Having this as a bonus action option makes it much more viable for characters who also want to attack on the same turn they reposition.

title: Tumble*
subtitle: Tumble through a hostile space
description: As an action or bonus action, attempt to deftly move through a hostile creature's space with a contested Acrobatics check.

bullets.content: As an agile alternative to Overrun, Tumble allows dexterous characters to slip past an opponent, relying on acrobatics instead of raw strength. It can be used as an action or a bonus action.

items: As an action or a bonus action, the tumbler makes a Dexterity (Acrobatics) check contested by the hostile creature's Dexterity (Acrobatics) check.
If the tumbler wins the contest, it can move through the hostile creature's space once this turn.

bullets.content: This is an excellent bonus action for mobile characters like Monks or Rogues to navigate a crowded battlefield without sacrificing their main action.

title: Drink a Potion**
subtitle: Quaff a potion quickly
description: A very common house rule to make potions more viable in combat by allowing you to drink one as a bonus action.
reference: Based on 'Use an Object' action, PHB 2024, pg. 294.

bullets.content: By rule, drinking a potion requires an action. This popular homebrew speeds up self-healing, making potions a more attractive option in the heat of battle by changing the action cost.

items: RAW: Using a magic item like a potion requires the Use an Object action.
Variant 1 (Most Common): You can drink a potion yourself as a Bonus Action. Administering a potion to another creature remains an Action.

Variant 2 (Uncommon): You can drink a potion as a Bonus Action to roll for healing. If you use your Action, you gain the maximum possible healing from the potion. This adds a tactical choice between speed and efficacy.

bullets.content: Adopting this rule can significantly change combat economy, allowing characters to both heal and contribute offensively in the same turn.

title: Feint**
subtitle: Gain advantage on your attack
description: A house rule allowing a creature to use its bonus action to try and outwit an opponent, granting advantage on its own attack.

bullets.content: While the 2024 Rogue gets a similar ability via Cunning Action, this homebrew makes the option available to all characters, providing a non-magical way to gain advantage through trickery rather than brute force.

items: This mechanic is now officially an option for Rogues via their Cunning Action feature, but this can be a general option for all characters.
As a Bonus Action, make a Charisma (Deception) check contested by a target's Wisdom ( Insight) check.
If you succeed, you gain Advantage on your next attack roll against that creature this turn.

bullets.content: This is a great thematic fit for Swashbucklers or any character who relies on cunning as much as combat prowess.

title: Swap Weapons**
subtitle: Sheathe one, draw another
description: A house rule to streamline combat by allowing a character to sheathe one weapon and draw another as a bonus action.
reference: Based on 'Interact with an Object', PHB 2024, pg. 294.

bullets.content: This quality-of-life homebrew smooths out combat for characters who frequently switch between melee and ranged weapons, which is difficult under the standard rules for object interactions.

items: RAW: You get one free Object Interaction on your turn (e.g., draw a sword). To sheathe that sword and then draw another would require your Action for the second interaction.
Homebrew: As a Bonus Action, you can sheathe a weapon you're holding and draw a different one. This makes weapon switching more fluid for martial characters.

bullets.content: This is particularly helpful for characters with the Thrown Weapon Fighting style or those who need to switch from a two-handed weapon to have a hand free for spellcasting.
